description:
Aspergillus ibericus CBS 121593 is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It was first isolated in Spain and is classified under the section Nigri within the Aspergillus genus.

Aspergillus ibericus is a haploid, asexual fungus that reproduces through the formation of asexual spores called conidia. The fungal colony appears as a dense, velvety mat, typically green to black in color. Microscopically, the conidiophores (specialized stalks that bear the conidia) are smooth-walled and have a globose vesicle at the apex, which is characteristic of the Aspergillus genus.

Phylogenetic analysis based on DNA sequences has shown that Aspergillus ibericus is closely related to other members of the Aspergillus section Nigri, such as Aspergillus niger and Aspergillus tubingensis. However, it can be distinguished from these species by its unique morphological features and genetic differences.

Aspergillus ibericus is known to be a saprobic fungus, meaning it can derive nutrients from decaying organic matter in the environment. It has been isolated from various substrates, including soil, plant materials, and even industrial settings. The ecological role and potential applications of this species are still under investigation.
